October 2019

Welcome to the October 2019 edition 
of the Justia client newsletter!

Get the latest scoop on online marketing, read our digest of legal and SEO news from the past month, and peek inside the doors at Justia to see what our team has been doing.

Featured News

Collaborative Law Firm Part VI: The Fax is Dead, Long Live the Fax

In the most recent installment of our series on the tools and technologies your law firm needs, we discuss the continuing usefulness of faxes, and options for implementing this technology.
Read More

Tip of the Month

Add a Narrative Bio to Your Free Justia Lawyer Directory Profile

We recommend adding a well-written biography to your JLD profile that highlights your practice and shows off your passion for the law. While you may discuss your educational and professional experience, this section is really targeted for weaving a narrative about your entire practice so that a potential client can understand you and your law firm in a way that mere biographical facts cannot communicate. If you need assistance logging in to update your profile, please contact us.
Learn How

Tech News

Nearly 50 States’ Attorneys General Join In Antitrust Investigation of Google

A multistate bipartisan coalition of attorneys general has formed for the purpose of investigating Google and other big tech companies’ control of internet advertising markets.

California Passes Bill That Threatens Uber and Lyft’s Business Model

Landmark legislation recently passed in California would make it easier to classify more workers as employees, and could result in an overhaul of the rideshare business.

Web Scraping Doesn’t Violate Anti-Hacking Law, Appeals Court Rules

The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals rejected LinkedIn’s claims that a data analytics company’s scraping of public profiles on its platform violated the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

House Antitrust Panel Seeks Documents From 4 Big Tech Firms

Executives at Google, Amazon, Facebook, and Apple have received requests for email records and other communications as part of a Congressional investigation into big tech.

Featured Site of the Month

Elliott Law Group, PLLC

in Spokane Valley, WA and Coeur d'Alene, ID, recently launched 
their Justia website:

elliottlawgroup.com

SEO News

Google Explains Why Syndicators May Outrank Original Publishers

Despite Google’s efforts to give priority to the original source when ranking content, publishers who do not require syndicators to use canonical tags or blocking may be outranked.

Google Makes Changes to GMB Listings With Distance-Based Service Areas

As part of an ongoing phase-out process, all remaining Google My Business Listings using distance-based service areas will soon be changed to instead reflect the closest named area.

Organic Search Responsible For 53% of All Site Traffic, Paid 15% [Study]

New research indicates that organic and paid search drive almost 70% of trackable website traffic, with social media having remained flat at around 5% for the past five years.

Google Officially Adds Timestamps to Videos in Search Results

Google is introducing timestamps for YouTube videos that appear in search results, a move designed to make it easier for users to find content that is contained within a video.

Internet Stats

Share of Online Searches in 2019 (Mobile vs. Desktop)

Source: Search Engine Land

Make sure your website is mobile-optimized for your potential clients. Justia builds branded Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) that provide a faster user experience since they're lightweight, optimized for mobile downloads, and preloaded to a user's mobile browser when they're on a Google search results page.

Did You Know?

Google My Business Will No Longer Send Messaging Through SMS

On November 15th, Google My Business (GMB) messaging will move from SMS (texts) to the free GMB app. This means you will no longer receive an SMS when customers reach out to you via your GMB listing. You will need to download the free GMB app if you do not yet have it installed and then login to your Google account.

Social Media News

Facebook Plans Launch of Its Own “Supreme Court” for Handling Takedown Appeals

Facebook’s new Oversight Board will reportedly operate independently of the social media giant, and will have powers including directing the company to allow or remove content.

LinkedIn Now Has a Way for Users to Verify Their Skills

LinkedIn is offering professionals an array of skill assessments for things like software and coding languages as a means of demonstrating proficiency to prospective employers.

Instagram Posts Can Now Be Scheduled In Advance Through Facebook

Facebook business account holders now have the ability to use those accounts to schedule Instagram posts and IGTV videos up to six months ahead of time.

YouTube Says It Has Removed More Than 100K Videos Under New Hate Speech Rules

Pursuant to YouTube’s new policy against hate speech, the video-sharing platform has taken down more than 17,000 channels, 100,000 videos, and 500 million comments.

Legal Industry News

Algorithms Should Have Made Courts More Fair. What Went Wrong?

A study of Kentucky’s use of algorithms in making pretrial release decisions has revealed a system that is missing policy goals and creating new inequities for people of color.

Lawyers, Cybersecurity, and Data Breaches: Your Ethical Obligations

Current ethics authority requires lawyers to remain up-to-date on technology issues impacting their practice, and encourages them to proactively prepare for data breaches.

Legal Jobs Leap Upward in August

Reporting the highest number of legal jobs in a decade, the legal industry added over 4,000 jobs in August, representing an increase of almost 6,000 jobs since last August.

At $1.2 Billion, It’s Already a Record Year for Legal Tech Investment

With a few months still left in 2019, legal tech investments have already topped last year’s record amount of $1 billion, and are reported to be distributed across 41 companies.
